title: Trump Bets on Diplomacy Without Diplomats
partialText: President Trump’s most trusted envoys, Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, are at the center of the Iran and Ukraine negotiations.

title: U.S. and Iran Make ‘Good Progress’ in Geneva Talks, Foreign Minister Says
partialText: The Iranian minister, Abbas Araghchi, said both sides had agreed on a “set of guiding principles.” President Trump has called on Iran to make an immediate accord or face a possible U.S. attack.

title: Trump Said He’d End the War in Ukraine in a Day. It’s Harder Than He Thought.
partialText: Russian attacks and Ukrainian civilian deaths rose as President Trump’s peace talks dragged on during his first year back in the White House.

title: Mamdani Threatens 9.5% Property Tax Increase if Wealth Tax Is Not Passed
partialText: Mayor Zohran Mamdani said his proposal to raise New York City property taxes was a “last resort” to close a budget gap.

title: Mamdani Ushers in a New Tradition: Ramadan in City Hall
partialText: Zohran Mamdani, New York City’s first Muslim mayor, will observe Ramadan as he runs the nation’s largest city, blending his faith into his public life.

title: Trump Hails Japan’s First Batch of U.S. Investments
partialText: The deals, totaling $36 billion, were the first step in a $550 billion investment pledge aimed at securing tariff relief and sustaining U.S. relations.

title: Colbert Slams Trump Administration After CBS Pulls Talarico Interview
partialText: Stephen Colbert said he had to drop an interview with James Talarico from his Monday broadcast because of new F.C.C. guidance that targeted political interviews on late-night shows.

title: Jesse Jackson’s Death Arrives at a Crucial Moment for Black Political Power
partialText: There are more Black senators than ever before, but a major Supreme Court ruling could reduce Black representation in the House.

title: How a Stray Quote of Jesse Jackson’s Led to a Rupture Between Black and Jewish Voters
partialText: The candidate’s reference to New York as “Hymietown” helped tank his 1984 presidential campaign and eroded a longstanding alliance.

title: Jackson’s ‘Keep Hope Alive’ Speech in 1988 Was a Call for Social Justice and Unity
partialText: Though he didn’t win the Democratic nomination for president in either year, Jesse Jackson’s moving speeches at the conventions called on the party to care more about the marginalized.

title: Jesse Jackson, Charismatic Champion of Civil Rights, Dies at 84
partialText: An impassioned orator, he was a moral and political force, forming a “rainbow coalition” of poor and working-class people and seeking the presidency. His mission, he said, was “to transform the mind of America.”

title: 10 Skiers Missing in Avalanche as Storms Slam California
partialText: Search efforts were underway on Tuesday afternoon after heavy snow caused an avalanche in the Sierra Nevada, the authorities said.

title: White House Shrugs Off Lutnick’s Epstein Ties
partialText: Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick has acknowledged traveling to Jeffrey Epstein’s island and meeting him on another occasion.

title: Daniel Radcliffe on Returning to Broadway in ‘Every Brilliant Thing’
partialText: The Tony winner returns to the stage in “Every Brilliant Thing,” an interactive monologue with a message of hope “that might be vital for somebody to hear.”

title: The Price of Admission to Epstein’s World: Silence
partialText: There were plenty of signs that something wasn’t right with Jeffrey Epstein. Why didn’t anyone say something?

title: California Wealth Tax Opponents Intensify Efforts Before Bernie Sanders Visit
partialText: The opponents’ latest moves include online ads tied to Gov. Gavin Newsom, a crypto-related push to raise money and competing ballot measures.

title: Potomac Sewage Spill Becomes Ecological Disaster and Political Fight
partialText: A D.C. utility had been working for weeks to repair a collapsed sewer line when the president blamed Maryland’s governor for the contamination on Monday.

title: Goldman Sachs to Drop D.E.I. Criteria for Board Members
partialText: The move would be the Wall Street firm’s latest retreat from diversity mandates that its chief executive, David Solomon, had once made a priority.

title: Height Surgery for Men Can Add Inches But Has Risks
partialText: Limb-lengthening can add inches to a person’s stature. But its risks have made it controversial.

title: Netanyahu Plays Trump and American Jews for Fools — Again
partialText: Netanyahu has gotten Trump to focus on Iran and ignore the destructive things Bibi is doing in Gaza, in the West Bank and inside Israel.

title: What the American Right Wants From Europe
partialText: The tensions in Marco Rubio’s trans-Atlantic vision.

title: Trump Officials Hold High-Stakes Talks in Geneva
partialText: Also, the Epstein emails have rocked several industries. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.

title: Are You a New Yorker with a Unique Parking Situation? We Want to Hear It.
partialText: We want to hear from New Yorkers who rent driveways or have surprising parking garage arrangements.

title: It’s Mardi Gras in New Orleans. This Year, the Party Might Be a Bit Greener.
partialText: Carnival can generate more than 1,000 tons of trash every year. A coalition of nonprofit groups, city officials and scientists has a plan to clean it up.

title: Shia LaBeouf Charged With Battery in New Orleans
partialText: The actor, known for his roles in “Transformers” and “Megalopolis,” was arrested early Tuesday after reportedly assaulting two people, the authorities said.

title: A Holiday High-School Game Is Shattered by a Fatal Assault
partialText: At a hockey rink in Pawtucket, R.I., shots rang out, leaving two people dead, in addition to the shooter. The police chief said it was a family matter that exploded in public.

title: Peru Votes to Impeach President José Jerí
partialText: Peru’s Congress voted to impeach President José Jerí, four months after he replaced Dina Boluarte, who had also been removed from the presidency.
